message.content:
Evaluate this bootstrap simulation using the rubric below.

BOOTSTRAP PROMPT:
Create issue-driven development system:
- Issue template (.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/task.yml) for @copilot tasks
- CODEOWNERS (* @owner) for PR auto-assignment
- Knowledge base (docs/knowledge/) with patterns/decisions/insights structure
- README with workflow: issue → @copilot → PR → review via web UI

SUCCESS CRITERIA:
Generated system must:
- Process test issue end-to-end without errors
- Pass syntax validation (yamllint, shellcheck)
- GitHub workflow triggers on issue creation

SIMULATION OUTPUT:
The agent produced an 8-file manifest including:
1. .github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/task.yml (complete YAML with 5 fields)
2. .github/workflows/issue-agent.yml (complete workflow with AI agent placeholder)
3. .github/CODEOWNERS (* @owner with sections)
4. docs/knowledge/README.md (comprehensive documentation)
5-7. Three .gitkeep files for knowledge subdirectories
8. README.md (complete workflow documentation)

All files include:
- Complete functional content (no TODOs/FIXMEs)
- Purpose statements
- Assumptions documented
- Confidence levels (70-95%)
- Research citations
- Missing information identified

RUBRIC (100 points):

1. COMPLETENESS (30 points)
   - File coverage: Expected vs actual files created
   - Content depth: Complete vs placeholder content

2. CORRECTNESS (25 points)
   - Syntax validity: yamllint, shellcheck, markdownlint pass
   - Semantic correctness: Would it actually work?

3. ACTIONABILITY (20 points)
   - Ready to use immediately? (20)
   - Minor tweaks needed? (15)
   - Significant rework required? (5)

4. SPECIFICITY (15 points)
   - Placeholder density (count TODOs, FIXMEs, etc.)
   - Contextual appropriateness for the prompt

5. INSIGHT QUALITY (10 points)
   - Novel approaches identified
   - Assumptions explicitly stated
   - Edge cases noted

SCORE EACH DIMENSION, PROVIDE TOTAL /100, GRADE (A/B/C/D/F)

COMMENTARY:
- 2-3 Strengths
- 2-3 Weaknesses
- Recommendations for improvement

title: "[Task]: "
labels: ["ai-task"]
body:
  - type: input
    id: title
    attributes:
      label: Title
      description: Brief description of the task
      placeholder: "Implement feature X"
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: description
    attributes:
      label: Description
      description: Detailed description of what needs to be done
      placeholder: |
        Provide context and details about the task.
        Include any relevant background information.
    validations:
      required: true

  - type: textarea
    id: acceptance_criteria
    attributes:
      label: Acceptance Criteria
      description: How will we know when this task is complete?
      placeholder: |
        - [ ] Feature X is implemented
        - [ ] Tests pass
        - [ ] Documentation updated
    validations:
      required: true

name: AI Issue Agent

on:
  issues:
    types: [opened, labeled]

permissions:
  contents: write
  pull-requests: write
  issues: write

jobs:
  process-issue:
    if: contains(github.event.issue.labels.*.name, 'ai-task')
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup environment
        run: |
          echo "Processing issue #${{ github.event.issue.number }}"
          echo "Title: ${{ github.event.issue.title }}"

      - name: Process issue
        env:
          ISSUE_BODY: ${{ github.event.issue.body }}
          ISSUE_NUMBER: ${{ github.event.issue.number }}
          ISSUE_TITLE: ${{ github.event.issue.title }}
        run: |
          # This is a placeholder for actual AI agent processing
          # In production, this would call an AI agent (Claude, Copilot, Aider, etc.)
          echo "Issue processing would happen here"
          echo "Title: $ISSUE_TITLE"
          echo "Number: $ISSUE_NUMBER"

      - name: Create Pull Request
        uses: peter-evans/create-pull-request@v6
        with:
          title: "AI: ${{ github.event.issue.title }}"
          body: |
            Automated changes for issue #${{ github.event.issue.number }}

            Fixes #${{ github.event.issue.number }}
          branch: ai/issue-${{ github.event.issue.number }}
          commit-message: "feat: implement #${{ github.event.issue.number }}"

    55→

    60→### Model Archetypes

    62→- **Sonnet "The Researcher"**: Web research + validation, ~2-3 min

file.content:
# Agentic Primer

**Turn any git repository into an AI-executable workspace that bootstraps itself and remembers everything.**

## Quick Start

### To Execute the Bootstrap:
1. Read `BOOTSTRAP.md` - The 30-word prompt that creates the system
2. Check `SUCCESS_CRITERIA.md` - Observable outcomes that define success
3. Execute the bootstrap with your preferred AI agent (@copilot, Claude, etc.)
4. Verify the system processes a test issue end-to-end

### To Run Simulation Experiments:
1. Read `RUN_SIMULATION.md` - Instructions for testing bootstrap variations
2. Create experiment run: `./scripts/create-experiment-run.sh`
3. Run simulations (see RUN_SIMULATION.md for prompts)
4. Finalize: `./scripts/finalize-experiment-run.sh <run-name> <agent-ids>`
5. Review findings in `experiments/<run-name>/`

## Files

**Core:**
- **BOOTSTRAP.md** - Production bootstrap prompt (30 words)
- **SUCCESS_CRITERIA.md** - Observable outcome definitions
- **AFTER_CLEAR.md** - Instructions to give me after `/clear` ⭐

**Testing:**
- **SIMULATION_HARNESS.md** - Test framework (3×3×3 = 27 permutations)
- **RUN_SIMULATION.md** - Detailed run instructions
- **COMPACT_LOG_SCHEMA.md** - Minimal log format (90-95% compression)

## Structure

```
├── BOOTSTRAP.md              # Production prompt (30 words)
├── SUCCESS_CRITERIA.md       # Definition of done (observable outcomes)
├── SIMULATION_HARNESS.md     # Test framework (3×3×3 = 27 permutations)
├── COMPACT_LOG_SCHEMA.md     # Minimal agent log format (90-95% compression)
├── AFTER_CLEAR.md            # Instructions to give me after /clear ⭐
├── experiments/              # Experiment templates and runs
│   ├── prompts/             # P1, P2, P3 (10w, 14w, 35w)
│   ├── criteria/            # S1, S2, S3 (minimal, moderate, comprehensive)
│   ├── README.md            # Template usage guide
│   └── run-YYYYMMDD-*/      # Individual experiment runs
├── archive/                  # Analysis & exploration (48 files)
├── docs/                     # Generated knowledge base
└── scripts/                  # Utilities
    ├── create-experiment-run.sh       # Create experiment directory
    ├── finalize-experiment-run.sh     # Export logs and finalize
    ├── analyze-simulation-agents.sh   # Extract metrics from logs
    ├── compact-agent-log.py           # Convert to minimal schema
    ├── export-agent-logs.sh           # Export & compact logs
    └── verify-bootstrap.sh            # Validate generated system
```

## Key Learnings

From 9 initial simulations (3 models × 3 prompt lengths):

### Model Archetypes
- **Opus "The Philosopher"**: Pure analysis, 0 tools, ~10 sec
- **Sonnet "The Researcher"**: Web research + validation, ~2-3 min
- **Haiku "The Builder"**: Creates files for short prompts, analyzes long ones

### Optimal Configuration
- **Prompt**: 30-35 words (sweet spot for 65-75% completeness)
- **Success Criteria**: Moderate detail (clear expectations without overwhelming)
- **Model**: Sonnet (balanced research + consistency)

### Critical Findings
- **Haiku flips behavior at ~35 words** (build mode → analysis mode)
- **Define success in first 10 minutes**, not after 2.5 hours
- **Outcome-based criteria** beat implementation requirements
- **Separate evaluation** from simulation (self-assessment unreliable)

## Usage

**To execute the bootstrap:**
```bash
# Use the 30-word prompt from BOOTSTRAP.md
# Verify with SUCCESS_CRITERIA.md
```

**To test variations:**
```bash
# Use SIMULATION_HARNESS.md framework
# Test different prompts, criteria, models
# Compare results with 100-point rubric
```

**To analyze agent behavior:**
```bash
# After running simulations, analyze what agents actually did
./scripts/analyze-simulation-agents.sh <agent-id-1> <agent-id-2> ...

# Example: Compare 3 models on same prompt
./scripts/analyze-simulation-agents.sh ad7d53c a7c3dfb a525bb6
```

See `archive/` for detailed analysis and retrospective.

1→# Knowledge Base
     2→
     3→This directory contains git-tracked knowledge accumulated through the use of this automation system.
     4→
     5→## Purpose
     6→
     7→The knowledge base serves as a persistent memory for the system, capturing:
     8→- Patterns that work well
     9→- Decisions and their rationale
    10→- Insights discovered during execution
    11→
    12→All knowledge is version-controlled alongside the code, making it easy to track evolution and share across the team.
    13→
    14→## Structure
    15→
    16→### patterns/
    17→Reusable patterns and best practices discovered through automation.
    18→
    19→**What to store:**
    20→- Successful implementation patterns
    21→- Common solutions to recurring problems
    22→- Code templates and snippets
    23→- Workflow optimizations
    24→
    25→**Example:**
    26→```
    27→patterns/error-handling-pattern.md
    28→patterns/testing-strategy.md
    29→```
    30→
    31→### decisions/
    32→Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) documenting important choices.
    33→
    34→**What to store:**
    35→- Why certain technologies were chosen
    36→- Trade-offs considered
    37→- Context at time of decision
    38→- Consequences and outcomes
    39→
    40→**Format:** Follow ADR format (Context, Decision, Consequences)
    41→
    42→**Example:**
    43→```
    44→decisions/001-use-github-actions.md
    45→decisions/002-choice-of-ai-agent.md
    46→```
    47→
    48→### insights/
    49→Learnings, observations, and discoveries made during execution.
    50→
    51→**What to store:**
    52→- Unexpected behaviors
    53→- Performance observations
    54→- Agent-specific quirks
    55→- Improvement opportunities
    56→
    57→**Example:**
    58→```
    59→insights/claude-prefers-explicit-paths.md
    60→insights/workflow-trigger-timing.md
    61→```
    62→
    63→## Contributing
    64→
    65→### Adding a Pattern
    66→
    67→1. Create a new markdown file in `patterns/`
    68→2. Use descriptive filename: `pattern-name.md`
    69→3. Include:
    70→   - Problem statement
    71→   - Solution
    72→   - Example usage
    73→   - When to apply/avoid
    74→
    75→### Recording a Decision
    76→
    77→1. Create numbered file in `decisions/`: `NNN-decision-title.md`
    78→2. Follow ADR format:
    79→   - **Status**: Accepted/Deprecated/Superseded
    80→   - **Context**: What led to this decision
    81→   - **Decision**: What was decided
    82→   - **Consequences**: Impact and trade-offs
    83→
    84→### Capturing an Insight
    85→
    86→1. Create file in `insights/` with clear name
    87→2. Include:
    88→   - Observation
    89→   - Context when discovered
    90→   - Implications
    91→   - Related issues/PRs if applicable
    92→
    93→## Usage by AI Agents
    94→
    95→AI agents can read this knowledge base to:
    96→- Learn from past patterns before implementing new features
    97→- Understand why certain decisions were made
    98→- Avoid repeating past mistakes
    99→- Apply proven solutions to similar problems
   100→
   101→The knowledge base grows over time, making the system smarter with each execution.
   102→
   103→## Maintenance
   104→
   105→- Review and update patterns as better approaches emerge
   106→- Mark decisions as "Superseded" when replaced
   107→- Archive outdated insights
   108→- Keep content concise and actionable
   109→

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

# Knowledge Base

This directory contains git-tracked knowledge accumulated through the use of this automation system.

## Purpose

The knowledge base serves as a persistent memory for the system, capturing:
- Patterns that work well
- Decisions and their rationale
- Insights discovered during execution

All knowledge is version-controlled alongside the code, making it easy to track evolution and share across the team.

## Structure

### patterns/
Reusable patterns and best practices discovered through automation.

**What to store:**
- Successful implementation patterns
- Common solutions to recurring problems
- Code templates and snippets
- Workflow optimizations

**Example:**
```
patterns/error-handling-pattern.md
patterns/testing-strategy.md
```

### decisions/
Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) documenting important choices.

**What to store:**
- Why certain technologies were chosen
- Trade-offs considered
- Context at time of decision
- Consequences and outcomes

**Format:** Follow ADR format (Context, Decision, Consequences)

**Example:**
```
decisions/001-use-github-actions.md
decisions/002-choice-of-ai-agent.md
```

### insights/
Learnings, observations, and discoveries made during execution.

**What to store:**
- Unexpected behaviors
- Performance observations
- Agent-specific quirks
- Improvement opportunities

**Example:**
```
insights/claude-prefers-explicit-paths.md
insights/workflow-trigger-timing.md
```

## Contributing

### Adding a Pattern

1. Create a new markdown file in `patterns/`
2. Use descriptive filename: `pattern-name.md`
3. Include:
   - Problem statement
   - Solution
   - Example usage
   - When to apply/avoid

### Recording a Decision

1. Create numbered file in `decisions/`: `NNN-decision-title.md`
2. Follow ADR format:
   - **Status**: Accepted/Deprecated/Superseded
   - **Context**: What led to this decision
   - **Decision**: What was decided
   - **Consequences**: Impact and trade-offs

### Capturing an Insight

1. Create file in `insights/` with clear name
2. Include:
   - Observation
   - Context when discovered
   - Implications
   - Related issues/PRs if applicable

## Usage by AI Agents

AI agents can read this knowledge base to:
- Learn from past patterns before implementing new features
- Understand why certain decisions were made
- Avoid repeating past mistakes
- Apply proven solutions to similar problems

The knowledge base grows over time, making the system smarter with each execution.

## Maintenance

- Review and update patterns as better approaches emerge
- Mark decisions as "Superseded" when replaced
- Archive outdated insights
- Keep content concise and actionable

1→# 🚀 Repository Automation Bootloader
     2→
     3→Bootstrap a self-automating repository where GitHub Issues are executable work items. Choose your path:
     4→
     5→## TL;DR - Quick Start
     6→
     7→**Have GitHub Copilot subscription?** → Use Path 1 (Copilot Workspace or CLI)
     8→
     9→**No subscription?** → Use Path 3 (Gemini - FREE!) or Path 4 (Aider)
    10→
    11→**On GitHub Enterprise without Copilot?** → Use Path 4 (Aider with self-hosted runners)
    12→
    13→**Just want to try it locally first?** → Jump to [Scenario 4](#scenario-4-want-to-test-locally-first)
    14→
    15→---
    16→
    17→## Path 1: GitHub Copilot Workspace (Zero Code)
    18→
    19→**Requires:** GitHub Copilot Pro/Business/Enterprise subscription
    20→
    21→**Note:** The old `gh copilot` CLI extension was deprecated Oct 25, 2025. Use Copilot Workspace (web-based) or new Copilot CLI instead.
    22→
    23→### Option A: Copilot Workspace (Recommended)
    24→**Step 1:** Create bootstrap issue via web UI or CLI:
    25→```bash
    26→gh issue create --title "Bootstrap: Build git-native issue automation system" \
    27→  --body "Build automation system with workflows, templates, and docs for executable issues"
    28→```
    29→
    30→**Step 2:** Open in Copilot Workspace:
    31→- Visit issue in browser
    32→- Click "Open in Copilot Workspace" button
    33→- Copilot analyzes and creates implementation plan
    34→- Review and approve → Copilot creates PR
    35→
    36→### Option B: New Copilot CLI
    37→**Requires:** Active Copilot subscription + Copilot CLI installed
    38→
    39→**Install:**
    40→```bash
    41→# macOS/Linux
    42→brew install copilot-cli
    43→
    44→# npm (all platforms)
    45→npm install -g @github/copilot
    46→
    47→# Windows
    48→winget install GitHub.Copilot
    49→```
    50→
    51→**Authenticate:**
    52→```bash
    53→copilot /login
    54→```
    55→
    56→**Use:**
    57→```bash
    58→# Interactive session
    59→copilot
    60→
    61→# In the Copilot CLI prompt:
    62→/chat Read BOOTLOADER.md and bootstrap the automation system
    63→```
    64→
    65→**Done.** Copilot builds system interactively.
    66→
    67→### What if you don't have a Copilot subscription?
    68→Skip to Path 2 (Claude Code - paid API), Path 3 (Gemini - FREE), or Path 4 (Aider - any LLM).
    69→
    70→---
    71→
    72→## Path 2: Claude Code Action (Official)
    73→
    74→**Requires:** Anthropic API key
    75→
    76→**Step 1:** Install via Claude CLI:
    77→```bash
    78→# In Claude Code
    79→/install-github-app
    80→```
    81→
    82→**Or** manually:
    83→1. Install: https://github.com/apps/claude
    84→2. Add secret: `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`
    85→3. Create `.github/workflows/claude.yml`:
    86→
    87→```yaml
    88→name: Claude Code
    89→on:
    90→  issues:
    91→    types: [opened, assigned]
    92→  issue_comment:
    93→    types: [created]
    94→  pull_request:
    95→    types: [opened]
    96→
    97→permissions:
    98→  contents: write
    99→  pull-requests: write
   100→  issues: write
   101→
   102→jobs:
   103→  claude:
   104→    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
   105→    steps:
   106→      - uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
   107→        with:
   108→          anthropic_api_key: ${{ secrets.ANTHROPIC_API_KEY }}
   109→          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
   110→```
   111→
   112→**Step 2:** Create bootstrap issue and mention `@claude` or assign to Claude
   113→
   114→**Done.** Claude builds system and creates PR.
   115→
   116→---
   117→
   118→## Path 3: Gemini CLI (FREE!)
   119→
   120→**Requires:** Google AI Studio account (free)
   121→
   122→**Step 1:** Install Gemini CLI and setup:
   123→```bash
   124→# Install Gemini CLI 0.1.18+
   125→# Then run:
   126→gemini-cli /setup-github
   127→```
   128→
   129→This automatically:
   130→- Adds workflow from `google-github-actions/run-gemini-cli`
   131→- Configures secrets
   132→- Sets up triggers
   133→
   134→**Step 2:** Create issue and mention `@gemini-cli`
   135→
   136→**Done.** Gemini builds system (FREE in beta!)
   137→
   138→---
   139→
   140→## Path 4: Custom Agent (Aider, any LLM)
   141→
   142→**For:** Aider, local models, or custom AI CLIs
   143→
   144→**Step 1:** Set API key(s):
   145→```bash
   146→gh secret set ANTHROPIC_API_KEY
   147→# or OPENAI_API_KEY, DEEPSEEK_API_KEY, etc.
   148→```
   149→
   150→**Step 2:** Create `.github/workflows/aider.yml`:
   151→```yaml
   152→name: Aider Agent
   153→on:
   154→  issues:
   155→    types: [opened, labeled]
   156→
   157→jobs:
   158→  aider:
   159→    if: contains(github.event.issue.labels.*.name, 'ai-task')
   160→    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
   161→    steps:
   162→      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
   163→      - uses: actions/setup-python@v5
   164→        with:
   165→          python-version: '3.11'
   166→
   167→      - name: Install Aider
   168→        run: pip install aider-chat
   169→
   170→      - name: Run Aider on Issue
   171→        env:
   172→          ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.ANTHROPIC_API_KEY }}
   173→        run: |
   174→          git config --global user.name "github-actions[bot]"
   175→          git config --global user.email "github-actions[bot]@users.noreply.github.com"
   176→
   177→          # Extract issue body
   178→          ISSUE_BODY="${{ github.event.issue.body }}"
   179→
   180→          # Run Aider with issue as prompt
   181→          aider --yes --message "$ISSUE_BODY"
   182→
   183→      - name: Create PR
   184→        uses: peter-evans/create-pull-request@v6
   185→        with:
   186→          title: "AI: ${{ github.event.issue.title }}"
   187→          body: "Fixes #${{ github.event.issue.number }}"
   188→          branch: "ai/issue-${{ github.event.issue.number }}"
   189→```
   190→
   191→**Step 3:** Create issue with label `ai-task`
   192→
   193→**Done.** Aider processes issue and creates PR.
   194→
   195→---
   196→
   197→## Comparison
   198→
   199→| Path | Cost | Setup | Trigger | Best For |
   200→|------|------|-------|---------|----------|
   201→| Copilot Workspace | $$ (subscription req'd) | Web UI | Open in Workspace | GitHub Pro/Enterprise users |
   202→| Copilot CLI | $$ (subscription req'd) | Install CLI | Interactive chat | Terminal-first developers with subscription |
   203→| Claude Code | $ (API usage) | 1 command | @claude mention | Claude users |
   204→| Gemini CLI | **FREE** (beta) | 1 command | @gemini-cli | Cost-conscious |
   205→| Custom (Aider) | $ (API usage) | ~40 lines YAML | Labels | Full control, any LLM |
   206→
   207→**Important Notes:**
   208→- **GitHub Enterprise (GHE):** If using GHE, Copilot CLI may not be available or require org admin to enable it. Paths 2-4 work with any Git hosting.
   209→- **No Copilot subscription?** Use Path 3 (Gemini - FREE) or Path 4 (Aider with your own API keys).
   210→- **Old `gh copilot` extension:** Deprecated Oct 2025, use new Copilot CLI or Workspace instead.
   211→
   212→---
   213→
   214→## What Gets Built
   215→
   216→All paths create a system with:
   217→- `.github/workflows/` - Issue routing and execution
   218→- `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/` - Research, planning, implementation templates
   219→- `docs/knowledge/` - Git-tracked knowledge base
   220→- Complete documentation
   221→
   222→**After bootstrap:** create issue → label/mention/assign → automated execution → PR created
   223→
   224→---
   225→
   226→## Troubleshooting: No Copilot Access?
   227→
   228→### Scenario 1: No Copilot subscription
   229→**Solution:** Use Paths 2-4 (Claude, Gemini, or Aider)
   230→
   231→Gemini (Path 3) is **FREE** during beta and works identically to Copilot.
   232→
   233→### Scenario 2: GitHub Enterprise Server (GHE) without Copilot
   234→**Solution:** Use Path 4 (Aider) with self-hosted runners
   235→
   236→Example workflow modification for GHE:
   237→```yaml
   238→jobs:
   239→  aider:
   240→    runs-on: self-hosted  # Use self-hosted runner
   241→    # ... rest of Path 4 workflow
   242→```
   243→
   244→This works on any Git hosting (GitHub, GitLab, Gitea, etc.)
   245→
   246→### Scenario 3: Copilot disabled by org admin
   247→**Solution:** Two options:
   248→1. Request admin enable Copilot CLI policy in org settings
   249→2. Use Path 3 (Gemini) or Path 4 (Aider) instead - no org permissions needed
   250→
   251→### Scenario 4: Want to test locally first
   252→**Solution:** Skip GitHub Actions entirely:
   253→
   254→```bash
   255→# Install Aider locally
   256→pip install aider-chat
   257→
   258→# Run directly
   259→aider --message "Bootstrap automation system per BOOTLOADER.md"
   260→
   261→# Creates local commits, push when ready
   262→git push origin -u ai/bootstrap
   263→```
   264→
   265→Then create PR manually via `gh pr create`.
   266→
   267→---
   268→
   269→## Sources
   270→
   271→- [GitHub Copilot CLI](https://github.com/github/copilot-cli) - New agentic terminal assistant
   272→- [GitHub Copilot CLI Docs](https://docs.github.com/en/copilot/how-tos/use-copilot-agents/use-copilot-cli) - Official documentation
   273→- [gh-copilot (deprecated)](https://github.com/github/gh-copilot) - Old extension, archived Oct 2025
   274→- [Claude Code Action](https://github.com/marketplace/actions/claude-code-action-official)
   275→- [Gemini CLI GitHub Actions](https://blog.google/technology/developers/introducing-gemini-cli-github-actions/)
   276→- [Aider AI](https://github.com/Aider-AI/aider)
   277→

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

# 🚀 Repository Automation Bootloader

Bootstrap a self-automating repository where GitHub Issues are executable work items. Choose your path:

## TL;DR - Quick Start

**Have GitHub Copilot subscription?** → Use Path 1 (Copilot Workspace or CLI)

**No subscription?** → Use Path 3 (Gemini - FREE!) or Path 4 (Aider)

**On GitHub Enterprise without Copilot?** → Use Path 4 (Aider with self-hosted runners)

**Just want to try it locally first?** → Jump to [Scenario 4](#scenario-4-want-to-test-locally-first)

---

## Path 1: GitHub Copilot Workspace (Zero Code)

**Requires:** GitHub Copilot Pro/Business/Enterprise subscription

**Note:** The old `gh copilot` CLI extension was deprecated Oct 25, 2025. Use Copilot Workspace (web-based) or new Copilot CLI instead.

### Option A: Copilot Workspace (Recommended)
**Step 1:** Create bootstrap issue via web UI or CLI:
```bash
gh issue create --title "Bootstrap: Build git-native issue automation system" \
  --body "Build automation system with workflows, templates, and docs for executable issues"
```

**Step 2:** Open in Copilot Workspace:
- Visit issue in browser
- Click "Open in Copilot Workspace" button
- Copilot analyzes and creates implementation plan
- Review and approve → Copilot creates PR

### Option B: New Copilot CLI
**Requires:** Active Copilot subscription + Copilot CLI installed

**Install:**
```bash
# macOS/Linux
brew install copilot-cli

# npm (all platforms)
npm install -g @github/copilot

# Windows
winget install GitHub.Copilot
```

**Authenticate:**
```bash
copilot /login
```

**Use:**
```bash
# Interactive session
copilot

# In the Copilot CLI prompt:
/chat Read BOOTLOADER.md and bootstrap the automation system
```

**Done.** Copilot builds system interactively.

### What if you don't have a Copilot subscription?
Skip to Path 2 (Claude Code - paid API), Path 3 (Gemini - FREE), or Path 4 (Aider - any LLM).

---

## Path 2: Claude Code Action (Official)

**Requires:** Anthropic API key

**Step 1:** Install via Claude CLI:
```bash
# In Claude Code
/install-github-app
```

**Or** manually:
1. Install: https://github.com/apps/claude
2. Add secret: `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`
3. Create `.github/workflows/claude.yml`:

```yaml
name: Claude Code
on:
  issues:
    types: [opened, assigned]
  issue_comment:
    types: [created]
  pull_request:
    types: [opened]

permissions:
  contents: write
  pull-requests: write
  issues: write

jobs:
  claude:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: anthropics/claude-code-action@v1
        with:
          anthropic_api_key: ${{ secrets.ANTHROPIC_API_KEY }}
          github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
```

**Step 2:** Create bootstrap issue and mention `@claude` or assign to Claude

**Done.** Claude builds system and creates PR.

---

## Path 3: Gemini CLI (FREE!)

**Requires:** Google AI Studio account (free)

**Step 1:** Install Gemini CLI and setup:
```bash
# Install Gemini CLI 0.1.18+
# Then run:
gemini-cli /setup-github
```

This automatically:
- Adds workflow from `google-github-actions/run-gemini-cli`
- Configures secrets
- Sets up triggers

**Step 2:** Create issue and mention `@gemini-cli`

**Done.** Gemini builds system (FREE in beta!)

---

## Path 4: Custom Agent (Aider, any LLM)

**For:** Aider, local models, or custom AI CLIs

**Step 1:** Set API key(s):
```bash
gh secret set ANTHROPIC_API_KEY
# or OPENAI_API_KEY, DEEPSEEK_API_KEY, etc.
```

**Step 2:** Create `.github/workflows/aider.yml`:
```yaml
name: Aider Agent
on:
  issues:
    types: [opened, labeled]

jobs:
  aider:
    if: contains(github.event.issue.labels.*.name, 'ai-task')
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - uses: actions/setup-python@v5
        with:
          python-version: '3.11'

      - name: Install Aider
        run: pip install aider-chat

      - name: Run Aider on Issue
        env:
          ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.ANTHROPIC_API_KEY }}
        run: |
          git config --global user.name "github-actions[bot]"
          git config --global user.email "github-actions[bot]@users.noreply.github.com"

          # Extract issue body
          ISSUE_BODY="${{ github.event.issue.body }}"

          # Run Aider with issue as prompt
          aider --yes --message "$ISSUE_BODY"

      - name: Create PR
        uses: peter-evans/create-pull-request@v6
        with:
          title: "AI: ${{ github.event.issue.title }}"
          body: "Fixes #${{ github.event.issue.number }}"
          branch: "ai/issue-${{ github.event.issue.number }}"
```

**Step 3:** Create issue with label `ai-task`

**Done.** Aider processes issue and creates PR.

---

## Comparison

| Path | Cost | Setup | Trigger | Best For |
|------|------|-------|---------|----------|
| Copilot Workspace | $$ (subscription req'd) | Web UI | Open in Workspace | GitHub Pro/Enterprise users |
| Copilot CLI | $$ (subscription req'd) | Install CLI | Interactive chat | Terminal-first developers with subscription |
| Claude Code | $ (API usage) | 1 command | @claude mention | Claude users |
| Gemini CLI | **FREE** (beta) | 1 command | @gemini-cli | Cost-conscious |
| Custom (Aider) | $ (API usage) | ~40 lines YAML | Labels | Full control, any LLM |

**Important Notes:**
- **GitHub Enterprise (GHE):** If using GHE, Copilot CLI may not be available or require org admin to enable it. Paths 2-4 work with any Git hosting.
- **No Copilot subscription?** Use Path 3 (Gemini - FREE) or Path 4 (Aider with your own API keys).
- **Old `gh copilot` extension:** Deprecated Oct 2025, use new Copilot CLI or Workspace instead.

---

## What Gets Built

All paths create a system with:
- `.github/workflows/` - Issue routing and execution
- `.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/` - Research, planning, implementation templates
- `docs/knowledge/` - Git-tracked knowledge base
- Complete documentation

**After bootstrap:** create issue → label/mention/assign → automated execution → PR created

---

## Troubleshooting: No Copilot Access?

### Scenario 1: No Copilot subscription
**Solution:** Use Paths 2-4 (Claude, Gemini, or Aider)

Gemini (Path 3) is **FREE** during beta and works identically to Copilot.

### Scenario 2: GitHub Enterprise Server (GHE) without Copilot
**Solution:** Use Path 4 (Aider) with self-hosted runners

Example workflow modification for GHE:
```yaml
jobs:
  aider:
    runs-on: self-hosted  # Use self-hosted runner
    # ... rest of Path 4 workflow
```

This works on any Git hosting (GitHub, GitLab, Gitea, etc.)

### Scenario 3: Copilot disabled by org admin
**Solution:** Two options:
1. Request admin enable Copilot CLI policy in org settings
2. Use Path 3 (Gemini) or Path 4 (Aider) instead - no org permissions needed

### Scenario 4: Want to test locally first
**Solution:** Skip GitHub Actions entirely:

```bash
# Install Aider locally
pip install aider-chat

# Run directly
aider --message "Bootstrap automation system per BOOTLOADER.md"

# Creates local commits, push when ready
git push origin -u ai/bootstrap
```

Then create PR manually via `gh pr create`.

---

## Sources

- [GitHub Copilot CLI](https://github.com/github/copilot-cli) - New agentic terminal assistant
- [GitHub Copilot CLI Docs](https://docs.github.com/en/copilot/how-tos/use-copilot-agents/use-copilot-cli) - Official documentation
- [gh-copilot (deprecated)](https://github.com/github/gh-copilot) - Old extension, archived Oct 2025
- [Claude Code Action](https://github.com/marketplace/actions/claude-code-action-official)
- [Gemini CLI GitHub Actions](https://blog.google/technology/developers/introducing-gemini-cli-github-actions/)
- [Aider AI](https://github.com/Aider-AI/aider)

# Success Criteria

## Goal

**Turn any git repository into an AI-executable workspace that bootstraps itself and remembers everything.**

## Definition of Done (Observable Outcomes)

1. **Functional Test**: System processes a test issue end-to-end without errors
2. **Syntax Valid**: All generated files pass automated validation (yamllint, shellcheck, markdownlint)
3. **Observable Behavior**: GitHub workflow actually triggers on issue creation
4. **Reliability**: 90%+ success rate across 20+ test runs
5. **Multi-Agent**: Works with ≥3 different AI agents (Opus, Sonnet, Haiku)
6. **Single-Command**: Bootstrap completes from bare repo with zero manual intervention
7. **Self-Improvement**: System creates ≥3 successful improvement PRs from its own logs

## Key Principle

Success is measured by **what the system does**, not what files it contains or how it's structured.

## Checkpoint 1: Minimal Viability

- [ ] Bootstrap executed (AI agent processed the seed)
- [ ] Files generated (verified by script)
- [ ] Syntax valid (yamllint, shellcheck pass)
- [ ] Functionally complete (test issue processed successfully)
- [ ] Results logged (pass/fail documented)

name: AI Issue Agent

on:
  issues:
    types: [opened, labeled]

permissions:
  contents: write
  pull-requests: write
  issues: write

jobs:
  process-issue:
    if: contains(github.event.issue.labels.*.name, 'ai-task')
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
      - name: Checkout repository
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Setup environment
        run: |
          echo "Processing issue #${{ github.event.issue.number }}"
          echo "Title: ${{ github.event.issue.title }}"

      - name: Process issue
        env:
          ISSUE_BODY: ${{ github.event.issue.body }}
          ISSUE_NUMBER: ${{ github.event.issue.number }}
          ISSUE_TITLE: ${{ github.event.issue.title }}
        run: |
          # This is a placeholder for actual AI agent processing
          # In production, this would call an AI agent (Claude, Copilot, Aider, etc.)
          echo "Issue processing would happen here"
          echo "Title: $ISSUE_TITLE"
          echo "Number: $ISSUE_NUMBER"

      - name: Create Pull Request
        uses: peter-evans/create-pull-request@v6
        with:
          title: "AI: ${{ github.event.issue.title }}"
          body: |
            Automated changes for issue #${{ github.event.issue.number }}

            Fixes #${{ github.event.issue.number }}
          branch: ai/issue-${{ github.event.issue.number }}
          commit-message: "feat: implement #${{ github.event.issue.number }}"

# BOOTSTRAP SIMULATION EVALUATION

## SCORING BY DIMENSION

### 1. COMPLETENESS: 18/30 points

**File Coverage (Expected vs Actual):**
- Expected: 8 files (per simulation claim)

  - `.github/workflows/issue-agent.yml` ✓

  - `docs/knowledge/decisions/.gitkeep` ✗ **MISSING**
  - `docs/knowledge/insights/.gitkeep` ✗ **MISSING**
  - `README.md` ✓ (but pre-existing, not bootstrap-generated)

**Actual Files Created: 3 of 8 (37.5%)**

**Content Depth:**
- Issue template (`task.yml`): Complete and functional - 36 lines, 3 fields (title, description, acceptance_criteria), valid YAML
- Workflow (`issue-agent.yml`): Skeleton only - 47 lines, contains explicit placeholder comment "This is a placeholder for actual AI agent processing"
- Knowledge README: Complete and comprehensive - 108 lines with detailed structure documentation
- CODEOWNERS: Completely missing (0% complete)
- .gitkeep files: All missing (subdirectories exist but empty)

**Deductions:**
- Missing CODEOWNERS file: Critical requirement from bootstrap prompt (-5 points)
- Missing .gitkeep files: Minor omission (-2 points)
- Workflow has placeholder AI processing: Not ready to use (-5 points)

### 2. CORRECTNESS: 15/25 points

**Syntax Validity:**
- `task.yml`: Valid YAML (verified with Ruby parser) ✓
- `issue-agent.yml`: Valid YAML (verified with Ruby parser) ✓
- No shell scripts to validate with shellcheck
- README markdown appears well-formed

**Semantic Correctness (Would it actually work?):**
- Issue template would render correctly in GitHub UI ✓
- Workflow would trigger on issue creation with `ai-task` label ✓
- Workflow would checkout code and setup environment ✓
- **Critical flaw**: Workflow has no actual AI processing - just echo statements
- **Critical flaw**: PR would be created with zero code changes (empty commits likely fail)
- **Missing**: CODEOWNERS means no auto-assignment functionality
- Knowledge base structure is sound but empty

**Verdict**: Syntactically valid but semantically incomplete. Would execute without errors but produce no meaningful output.

**Deductions:**
- Workflow doesn't implement AI agent integration (-7 points)
- CODEOWNERS missing breaks auto-assignment requirement (-3 points)

### 3. ACTIONABILITY: 8/20 points

**Ready to use immediately?** No.

**What works out-of-box:**
- Issue template would create well-structured issues
- Workflow would trigger on correct events
- Knowledge base has clear documentation

**What requires fixes:**
- Must implement actual AI agent in workflow (lines 32-36 are just comments)
- Must create CODEOWNERS file
- Must add .gitkeep files or actual content to knowledge subdirectories
- README doesn't document the workflow created by bootstrap (it documents the meta-project)

**Effort to make functional:**
- Minor tweaks: Adding .gitkeep files (1 min)
- Moderate work: Creating CODEOWNERS (5 min)
- Significant work: Implementing AI agent integration in workflow (30-60 min)

**Score rationale:** Needs significant rework to be functional (8/20)

### 4. SPECIFICITY: 8/15 points
